1.text: He began to speak to them in parables. “A man planted a vineyard, put a hedge around it, dug a pit for the winepress, and built a tower. He then rented it to tenant farmers and left for another country.

2.text: When it was time, he sent a slave to the farmers to receive his share of the fruit of the vineyard.

3.text: But they took the slave, beat him, and sent him away empty.

4.text: Again, the owner sent another slave to them, and they threw stones at him, wounded him in the head, and sent him away shamefully treated.

5.text: Again he sent another; and they killed him along with many others, beating some, and killing some.

6.text: The man still had one left to send, his beloved son. Finally, he sent him to them, saying: ‘They will respect my son!’

7.text: But the tenants of the vineyard saw him coming and said among themselves, ‘This is the heir! Come, let us kill him, and the inheritance will be ours!’

8.text: They took him, killed him, and threw him out of the vineyard.

9.text: What then will the lord of the vineyard do? He will come to destroy those farmers, and he will give the vineyard to others.

10.text: Have you not even read this Scripture:  ‘The very stone which the builders rejected,   Has become the head of the corner.

11.text: This is the Lord’s doing,   And it is marvelous in our eyes?’

12.text: They kept trying to arrest Jesus, but they feared the multitude because they understood that he had spoken the parable against them. So they left him and went away.

13.text: They sent some of the Pharisees and Herodians to Jesus, in order to trap him in what he said.

14.text: They came to him and said, “Teacher, we know that you are truthful, and that you are not afraid of anyone because you do not look at human rank but truly teach the way of God. Tell us therefore, is it lawful to pay taxes to Caesar, or not?

15.text: Shall we give, or shall we not give?” But knowing their hypocrisy, Jesus replied, “Why do you test me? Bring me a denarius, so that I may see it.”

16.text: They brought it. Jesus then asked them, “Whose image and inscription is this?” They answered, “Caesar’s.”

17.text: Jesus then replied to them, “Render to Caesar what belongs to Caesar, and to God what belongs to God.” And they were amazed at him.

18.text: After this, Sadducees (who say that there is no resurrection) came to him. They asked him,

19.text: “Teacher, Moses wrote to us, ‘If a man dies leaving a wife behind him but no children, his brother should take his wife, and raise up offspring for him.’

20.text: Now there were seven brothers. The first took a wife, died, and left no offspring.

21.text: The second [brother] took her and [also] died, and left no children behind him, either. The third likewise;

22.text: and so the seven [brothers] married her and left no children. Last of all, the woman also died.

23.text: Therefore, in the resurrection, when they rise, whose wife will she be? For the seven [brothers] had her as a wife.”

24.text: Jesus answered them, “Is this not why you are mistaken, by not knowing the Scriptures or the power of God?

25.text: For when people {will} rise from the dead, they do not marry nor are given in marriage; instead, they are like angels in heaven.

26.text: But regarding the fact that the dead are raised, have you not read in the book of Moses (in the passage about the bush), how God spoke to him, saying: ‘I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?’

27.text: He is not the God of the dead, but of the living! This is why you are greatly misled.”

28.text: One of the scribes came and heard them debating. Knowing that Jesus had answered them well, he asked him, “Which commandment is the greatest of all?”

29.text: Jesus answered him, “The greatest is, ‘Hear, Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is one:

30.text: you shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your mind, and with all your strength.’ This is the first commandment.

31.text: And the second is likewise, ‘You shall love your neighbor as yourself.’ There is no other commandment greater than these.”

32.text: The scribe said to him, “It is well, teacher, that you have said truly that he is one, and there is none other but he,

33.text: and to love him with the whole heart, with the whole mind, with the whole soul, and with the whole strength; and to love one’s neighbor as oneself. It is more important than any whole burnt-offerings and sacrifices.”

34.text: When Jesus saw that the scribe had answered wisely, he said to him, “You are not far from the Kingdom of God!” No one dared to ask him any [other] question after that.

35.text: As he taught in the temple, Jesus asked, “How is it that the scribes say that the Christ is the son of David?

36.text: For David himself said in the Holy Spirit:  The Lord said to my Lord,   Sit at my right hand,   until I make your enemies the footstool of your feet.

37.text: Therefore, David himself calls him Lord, so how can he be his son?” The large crowd listened to him with delight.

38.text: In his teaching, he told them, “Beware of the scribes! They like to walk in long robes, to be greeted in the marketplace,

39.text: and [to have] the best seats in the synagogues and at banquets.

40.text: They devour widows’ houses, and for a pretense say long prayers. Such men will be punished most severely.”

41.text: Jesus sat down opposite the treasury and watched the people putting their money into the treasury. Many who were rich gave much.

42.text: A poor widow came, and she put in two small coins, which amount to a quadrans coin.

43.text: He called his disciples to himself, and told them, “Amen, I tell you that this poor widow gave more than all those [others] who are giving to the treasury.

44.text: For they all gave out of their abundance, but she, out of her poverty, gave all that she had to live on.”
